Class ManagerController

java.lang.Object
app.ManagerController
public class ManagerController extends Object
Controller class that manages the manager view of the POS system.

Handles the user interface and interactions for inventory, employees, and order history management. Communicates with the database through DatabaseConnector and dynamically updates the display within mainDisplayPane.

Author:
Grant, Ryan, and Brenden

    Nested Classes

    Class

    Represents an inventory item within the restock management table.
    static class 
    ManagerController.TopItem
    Represents a top-selling menu item used in reports.

  • Field Details

    • mainDisplayPane

      private javafx.scene.layout.AnchorPane mainDisplayPane
      The main display area for loading manager interface content dynamically.

    • currDate

      private static LocalDate currDate
      The current date used across reports and database queries.

  • Constructor Details

    • ManagerController

      public ManagerController()

  • Method Details

    • setCurrDate

      public static void setCurrDate(String date)
      Sets the current date used by the manager dashboard. Primarily applied when generating daily or range-based reports.
      Parameters:
      date - the current date in YYYY-MM-DD format.

    • handleInventoryButton

      private void handleInventoryButton()
      Loads and displays the current inventory table from the database.

      Each record shows the ingredient name, available quantity, and its unit of measurement. The data is dynamically fetched using SQL.

    • handleOrdersButton

      private void handleOrdersButton()
      Loads and displays the most recent orders in the system.

      The query retrieves up to 40 of the latest orders and presents details including order ID, employee ID, order location, date, and total value.

    • handleEmployeeButton

      private void handleEmployeeButton()
      Displays the employee management table.

      Fetches employee information including ID, name, and position. Provides UI controls for adding or removing employees through showAddEmployeeForm() and removeSelectedEmployee(TableView).

    • handleRestockButton

      private void handleRestockButton()
      Handles the "Restock" button action from the Manager interface.

      When clicked, this triggers loadRestockTable() to display the interactive inventory restock table, where managers can update item quantities and view restock statuses.

    • loadTableFromQuery

      private void loadTableFromQuery(String query, String title)
      Loads a generic table from a given SQL query and displays it inside the main pane.

      This universal table loader is reused across multiple dashboard sections (e.g., inventory, orders, employees) to dynamically populate tabular data without hardcoding the schema.

      Parameters:
      query - SQL query used to fetch data from the database
      title - The display title shown above the generated table

    • loadRestockTable

      private void loadRestockTable()
      Loads the interactive restock management table into the main display pane.

      This method dynamically builds a table of all inventory items, their current quantities, and restock thresholds. Users can manually add quantities to restock individual items.

      Rows that meet or fall below their restock minimum threshold are visually highlighted with a light yellow background for quick identification.

    • updateInventory

      private void updateInventory(String ingredient, int addAmount)
      Updates the quantity of a specific inventory item in the database.

      This method increases the quantityAvailable field of the specified ingredient by the given addAmount. It also provides visual confirmation to the user through a JavaFX alert upon successful update.

      Parameters:
      ingredient - the name of the ingredient to restock
      addAmount - the amount to add to the current quantity

    • buildTableFromResultSet

      private javafx.scene.control.TableView<javafx.collections.ObservableList<String>> buildTableFromResultSet(ResultSet rs) throws SQLException
      Builds a JavaFX TableView dynamically from a SQL ResultSet.

      This method is used by multiple sections (e.g., inventory, orders, menu) to construct generic tables without needing predefined column names. Each column header is set according to the ResultSetMetaData.

      Parameters:
      rs - the ResultSet containing database query results
      Returns:
      a fully constructed TableView with populated data
      Throws:
      SQLException - if an SQL or data extraction error occurs

    • showAddEmployeeForm

      private void showAddEmployeeForm()
      Displays a dialog form to add a new employee to the database.

      This method opens a JavaFX Dialog window where the manager can enter the employee’s ID, name, position, and passcode. Upon submission, the form validates that the ID is numeric and calls addEmployeeToDatabase(int, String, String, String) to save the entry.

      If the user cancels or provides invalid data, appropriate alerts are displayed.

    • addEmployeeToDatabase

      private void addEmployeeToDatabase(int id, String name, String position, String passcode)
      Inserts a new employee record into the database.

      This method executes an INSERT SQL statement to add a new employee using the provided ID, name, position, and passcode. Upon success, a confirmation alert is displayed and the employee table view is refreshed by calling handleEmployeeButton().

      If a SQL error occurs (e.g., duplicate ID or connection failure), an error alert is displayed with diagnostic details.

      Parameters:
      id - the unique employee ID
      name - the employee's full name
      position - the role or position of the employee (e.g., Cashier, Manager)
      passcode - the password/passcode assigned to the employee

    • removeSelectedEmployee

      private void removeSelectedEmployee(javafx.scene.control.TableView<javafx.collections.ObservableList<String>> table)
      Removes the currently selected employee from the database.

      This method retrieves the selected row from the TableView and deletes the corresponding record from the database after confirmation. A warning alert is shown if no employee is selected, and a confirmation dialog ensures the user intends to proceed with deletion.

      After a successful deletion, the employee table view is refreshed.

      Parameters:
      table - the employee TableView from which the selected record is identified

    • handleMenuButton

      private void handleMenuButton()
      Handles the "Menu" button click on the Manager interface.

      This method displays the menu management table by retrieving all menu items from the database. The view allows managers to add, edit, or remove menu items using the corresponding buttons. The table is dynamically populated with data from the menu table in the database.

    • showAddMenuForm

      private void showAddMenuForm()
      Displays a dialog for adding a new menu item to the database.

      The dialog allows the manager to input a new item’s ID, name, category, price, and description. Upon clicking OK, the data is validated to ensure numeric fields are correctly formatted before being inserted into the database via addMenuItemToDatabase(int, String, String, double, String).

      If the input data is invalid (e.g., non-numeric ID or price), an error alert is displayed.

    • addMenuItemToDatabase

      private void addMenuItemToDatabase(int id, String name, String category, double price, String desc)
      Inserts a new menu item into the database.

      Executes an INSERT SQL statement to add a new record to the menu table with the provided details (ID, name, category, price, and description). A confirmation alert is shown upon success, and the menu view is refreshed.

      If a SQL error occurs (e.g., duplicate ID or invalid connection), an error alert is displayed with the failure message.

      Parameters:
      id - the unique identifier for the menu item
      name - the name of the menu item
      category - the menu category (e.g., "Milky Series", "Fruity Beverage")
      price - the item’s price
      desc - the item’s textual description

    • showEditMenuForm

      private void showEditMenuForm(javafx.scene.control.TableView<javafx.collections.ObservableList<String>> table)
      Displays a dialog for editing a selected menu item.

      This method retrieves the selected row from the menu table and populates editable text fields with the existing values. The user can modify the name, category, or price of the item. Upon confirmation, the data is validated and passed to updateMenuItem(int, String, String, double) for database update.

      If no item is selected or an invalid price is entered, an alert is displayed.

      Parameters:
      table - the TableView containing the list of menu items

    • updateMenuItem

      private void updateMenuItem(int id, String name, String category, double price)
      Updates an existing menu item in the database.

      Executes an UPDATE SQL statement to modify an existing menu record based on the provided ID. After successfully updating the record, a confirmation alert is shown and the menu table view is refreshed.

      If a database error occurs, an error alert is displayed with details of the failure.

      Parameters:
      id - the unique ID of the menu item to update
      name - the new menu name
      category - the new category (e.g., "Fruity Beverage", "Milky Series")
      price - the new price for the item

    • removeSelectedMenuItem

      private void removeSelectedMenuItem(javafx.scene.control.TableView<javafx.collections.ObservableList<String>> table)
      Removes a selected menu item from the database.

      This method checks the selected table row, confirms with the user via an alert dialog, and then executes a DELETE SQL statement to remove the item from the database. After successful removal, the menu list view is refreshed.

      If no item is selected or an SQL error occurs, the method displays an appropriate alert message.

      Parameters:
      table - the TableView containing the list of menu items

    • handleBackToLogin

      private void handleBackToLogin()
      Returns the user to the login screen.

      Loads the LoginView.fxml file and sets it as the current scene. This allows managers to safely log out and return to the main login view.

      If the FXML file cannot be loaded, an error alert is displayed.

    • handleReportsButton

      private void handleReportsButton()
      Displays the Sales Reports interface with options for various report types.

      The manager can generate:

      • X-Report (summary of current sales)
      • Z-Report (end-of-day report)
      • Range Report (custom date range totals)
      • Product Usage Chart
      This interface dynamically updates the mainDisplayPane with labels, totals, and tables populated from the database queries.

    • handleProductUsageChartButton

      private void handleProductUsageChartButton()
      Handles the "Product Usage Chart" button click on the Manager interface.

      This method prepares the layout and chart components for displaying ingredient usage across a selected time range. It initializes a BarChart with labeled axes for ingredient names and quantities used, and embeds it into the mainDisplayPane.

      The data population logic is handled separately via the report generation function once user inputs are selected.

    • generateReport

      private void generateReport(LocalDateTime start, LocalDateTime end, javafx.scene.control.Label totalRevenueLabel, javafx.scene.control.Label totalOrdersLabel, javafx.scene.control.TableView<ManagerController.TopItem> table)
      Generates a sales report within a specified time window.

      This method executes two SQL queries:

      • A totals query that retrieves total revenue and number of orders within the date range.
      • A top-selling items query that retrieves the top 5 grossing products and their revenue.

      Results are displayed by updating provided UI components: total revenue and order count labels, and a TableView showing ManagerController.TopItem objects.

      This helper is reusable for multiple report types (daily, weekly, range-based, etc.) that rely on consistent report aggregation logic.

      Parameters:
      start - the start of the reporting period (inclusive)
      end - the end of the reporting period (exclusive)
      totalRevenueLabel - label to update with total revenue
      totalOrdersLabel - label to update with total order count
      table - TableView to populate with top-selling items
